education.

equal.
"Faculty, men and women
alike, often inadvertently treat
women and men students dif-

her academic ability,"she said.

which both male and female
faculty members alienate women
in the classroom.
She began first with the more
overt forms of discrimination
such as verbal harassment or the
use of demeaning nicknames such
as "broad" or "chick." This
verbal abuse, she said, though unconsciously committed, is often
unintentional and demeans a
woman's intelligence, thus instilling self-doubt.

Alpha Epsilon Delta
sponsors MCAT lunch
by Matthew J. Lurin
On Saturday, September 19,
when most of you were still sleeping, the officers of Alpha Epsilon
Delta, the Pre-Med Honor Society, were preparing for the first
semi-annual Medical College Admission Test smorgasbord.
Many Hopkins students claim
that the MCAT should be a
school holiday, as it seems that
everyone goes through either the
agony of taking the test, or knows
someone who must. For those
few who do not know, the MCAT
is an all-day exam given twice a
year, and is required for admission to most medical schools.
It is now divided into seven
sections, including physics,
biology, chemistry, science problems, reading skills, quantitative
skills, and an essay. The exam
begins at 8 am and can go on until 8 pm. There are breaks between some sections, the longest
being an hour for lunch.
Many students feel pressure
and preparing a lunch is probably
the furthest thought from their
mind. Many students live ten to

fifteen minutes from campus, so
going home for lunch can be a
problem, and the tension that
goes with nerves does not mix
well with greasy fast foods, the
most likely answer. So enter
AED.
The Pre-Med Honor Society is
going through many changes. Its
officers believe that there is plenty of room for development here
at Hopkins, and they want to
remove its weak image of years
gone by.
Vice-President Glen Weiss said
that sponsoring a lunch for
MCATers is a step in the right
direction.
He said, "I feel that this is a
step in the right direction. We
need to show the school and the
student body that we take
ourselves seriously. We hope to
be more involved in the development of pre-meds here at Hopkins
and hope that events like this one
will bring the students closer
together."
About seventy-five people
dropped by for cold-cuts and
sodas, all free.

from high school, we all took part-time

important part of our country's military
defense.

Listen this year to scholars in the humanities and the
social sciences talk about their work and you hear the
sound of barriers coming down.
Reflecting on the present and future state of their fields,
scholars speak out about how the boundaries of their
disciplines are "extending" or "breaking down," about
how their own perspectives are "broadening." They talk
of "looking beyond themselves" and of "joining the
general intellectual conversation."
They are referring not so much to interdisciplinary work
—though that is prevalent—as to a continuing evolution
in their understanding of what constitutes history or
sociology or philosophy or literary studies. In field after
field, although the verses may be different, the refrain
is the same.
Specialists in religion, for example, are taking more
and more interest in developments outside their usual domain of sacred texts and doctrines, says Robert N. Bellah,
professor of sociology at the University of California at
Berkeley. "A continuing problem for theology," he says,
"is that it's marginal and in many ways considered illegitimate. That makes theologians want to find ways to
join the conversation, rather than being considered odd
and having these strange beliefs. The theologian who
wants to join the general intellectual conversation has to
be attuned to what's going on."
In history, says Paul Boyer, professor of history at the
University of Wisconsin at Madison, "the subdisciplines
are looking beyond themselves more than they have in
the past." He adds: "The best history is being done from

Struggling for Equality
This week's lecture by Bernice
Sandler, executive director of the Project on the Status and Education of
Women, brought to light the serious
lack of women in higher education.
Sandler spoke in detail about the many
ways in which a woman's confidence is,
often inadvertently, threatened in the
classroom or workplace; thus all women
may feel less qualified than men to perform in the academic and professional
worlds.
Two reports recently conducted in the
University of California and University of Virginia revealed that universities
have done little to recruit women for
their faculties and administrations. According to the California study, female
faculty are found more in junior and
women's colleges than in major universities. They are usually concentrated in
fields often associated with women,
such as English and education, and are
consistently paid less than their male
colleagues, at all levels.
Hopkins has traditionally proven to be
no exception to these attitudes towards
women. In December of 1984, the Ad
Hoc Committee on the Status of Women
was formed as a direct result of uproar
over the circulation of a graphic TEP
newsletter, which sexually defamed
women in general. At the time of the
committee's report that following July,
there were only eight tenured women in
the Homewood community; tenured and
tenure-track women made up only seven
percent of the of the entire faculty.
The Ad Hoc report alarmingly noted
that women are even more underrepre-

sented at Hopkins than at comparable
institutions; at that time, women made
up over 16 percent of the tenured and
tenure-track faculty of the top 50
doctorate-granting institutions in the
United States. The paper went on to
issue recommendations for improvements in employment and working conditions at Homewood,faculty hiring and
curriculum, and the establishment of a
Women's Center at Homewood.
The Committee's recommendations
have begun to manifest themselves. This
fall, seven women joined the
Homewood faculty as assistant professors. This represents 25 percent of
the new faculty hired this year, compared to five percent two years ago.
The new professors have each joined
a different department, ranging from
Physics and Astronomy to English. This
is encouraging news for the Homewood
community. But while steps have been
taken to increase the number of women
in the faculty, the transition has been
slow.
Lectures such as Sandler's achieve the
two-fold purpose of heightening
awareness of women's issues at
Homewood as well as providing the
community with the opportunity to hear
the words of some truly outstanding
women. But it is the department
chairmen and administration that really have the ability to balance the faculty ratio. It is our hope that they will, as
faculty positions become available,
perceive their female applicants not as
opportunities to fulfill a quota, but as
equals of their male competition.

A Landmark of History
Gilman Hall is embued with the kind
of history to which Hopkins University
should cling. It is named after Hopkins'
first president, Daniel Coit Gilman.
Even its architectural design was in part
conceived by an alumnus, Douglas H.
Thomas Jr., of the Baltimore firm,
Parker, Thomas and Rice. It is the embodiment of Hopkins' extension into the
fields of the Humanities and Social
Sciences.
The importance of Gilman does not
lie solely in its heritage. It is
Homewood's largest classroom and office facility. In addition, its size and
central location on campus have made
Gilman attractive for other services to
the community.
Furthermore, Gilman is. a beautiful
example of collegiate Georgian revival
style architecture. Preserving this example has become the concern of the Commission on Historic and Architectural
Preservation (CHAP). In City Council
Ordinance 1764, CHAP recommends
that Gilman be designated a historic
landmark.

The administration is resisting the
designation— and with good reason.
The ordinance, if passed, would require
that any proposed changes in Gilman's
exterior would have to obtain CHAP's
approval in addition to the existing requirements from city agencies.
Gilman's historical and emotional
role at Hopkins is sufficient to insure
that it will be well taken care of in the
future. The university does not have the
flexibility of space, however, not to
make the most of every building.
The services in the basement of
Gilman would be well incorporated into a student union, one much more comprehensive than Levering Hall is today.
Although such a student union is only
a hope for the not-too-distant future, the
freeing-up of that basement space
should be well used. Gilman's designation as a historic landmark would undoubtedly slow down, and might well
interfere with its effective use, while
protecting a landmark the university is
already very sensitive to protect.

Fall Preview
Hello, Hopkins student. Been studying hard? Your face buried in the books? Then you probably haven't had time to notice that there's a city
out there. That's right, that's not all wasteland between Homewood and the Harbor. Lots of students are noticing the first ways to get to know
a city is to know what's going on in it.
That's why there's this four-page pull-out. It has schedules and phone numbers you'll need to explore the cultural life of Baltimore. Sure, it's
not Washington D.C. But Baltimore does have culture. In the past, students have pretty much restricted themselves to the Homewood campus,
sometimes never venturing farther than Wawa. Go out there. See a play. See a movie. Attend a concert.
The shuttle can drop you off at Mt. Vernon Place, a major cultural center. Or, the 61 bus goes down St. Paul Street, and the 8 bus down
Greenmount. There are a lot of inexpensive things to do. And many expensive places have Student Rush tickets, where you get in for less than
a quarter the regular price if you just show up half an hour before performance and it's not sold out.
So pull this section out, and tack it to your wall. Wouldn't it be a waste to spend four years in Baltimore, and leave it knowing nothing about
the city except where the Rotunda is? You owe it to Baltimore, if not to yourself.

On Saturday, September 19,
when most of you were still sleeping, the officers of Alpha Epsilon
Delta, the Pre-Med Honor Society, were preparing for the first
semi-annual Medical College Admission Test smorgasbord.
Many Hopkins students claim
that the MCAT should be a
school holiday, as it seems that
everyone goes through either the
agony of taking the test, or knows
someone who must. For those
few who do not know, the MCAT
is an all-day exam given twice a
year, and is required for admission to most medical schools.
It is now divided into seven
sections, including physics,
biology, chemistry, science problems, reading skills, quantitative
skills, and an essay. The exam
begins at 8 am and can go on until 8 pm. There are breaks between some sections, the longest
being an hour for lunch.
Many students feel pressure
and preparing a lunch is probably
the furthest thought from their
mind. Many students live ten to

fifteen minutes from campus, so
going home for lunch can be a
problem, and the tension that
goes with nerves does not mix
well with greasy fast foods, the
most likely answer. So enter
AED.
The Pre-Med Honor Society is
going through many changes. Its
officers believe that there is plenty of room for development here
at Hopkins, and they want to
remove its weak image of years
gone by.
Vice-President Glen Weiss said
that sponsoring a lunch for
MCATers is a step in the right
direction.

Struggling for Equality
This week's lecture by Bernice
Sandler, executive director of the Project on the Status and Education of
Women, brought to light the serious
lack of women in higher education.
Sandler spoke in detail about the many
ways in which a woman's confidence is,
often inadvertently, threatened in the
classroom or workplace; thus all women
may feel less qualified than men to perform in the academic and professional
worlds.
Two reports recently conducted in the
University of California and University of Virginia revealed that universities
have done little to recruit women for
their faculties and administrations. According to the California study, female
faculty are found more in junior and
women's colleges than in major universities. They are usually concentrated in
fields often associated with women,
such as English and education, and are
consistently paid less than their male
colleagues, at all levels.
Hopkins has traditionally proven to be
no exception to these attitudes towards
women. In December of 1984, the Ad
Hoc Committee on the Status of Women
was formed as a direct result of uproar
over the circulation of a graphic TEP
newsletter, which sexually defamed
women in general. At the time of the
committee's report that following July,
there were only eight tenured women in
the Homewood community; tenured and
tenure-track women made up only seven
percent of the of the entire faculty.
The Ad Hoc report alarmingly noted
that women are even more underrepre-

sented at Hopkins than at comparable
institutions; at that time, women made
up over 16 percent of the tenured and
tenure-track faculty of the top 50
doctorate-granting institutions in the
United States. The paper went on to
issue recommendations for improvements in employment and working conditions at Homewood,faculty hiring and
curriculum, and the establishment of a
Women's Center at Homewood.
The Committee's recommendations
have begun to manifest themselves. This
fall, seven women joined the
Homewood faculty as assistant professors. This represents 25 percent of
the new faculty hired this year, compared to five percent two years ago.
The new professors have each joined
a different department, ranging from
Physics and Astronomy to English. This
is encouraging news for the Homewood
community. But while steps have been
taken to increase the number of women
in the faculty, the transition has been
slow.
Lectures such as Sandler's achieve the
two-fold purpose of heightening
awareness of women's issues at
Homewood as well as providing the
community with the opportunity to hear
the words of some truly outstanding
women. But it is the department
chairmen and administration that really have the ability to balance the faculty ratio. It is our hope that they will, as
faculty positions become available,
perceive their female applicants not as
opportunities to fulfill a quota, but as
equals of their male competition.

A Landmark of History
Gilman Hall is embued with the kind
of history to which Hopkins University
should cling. It is named after Hopkins'
first president, Daniel Coit Gilman.
Even its architectural design was in part
conceived by an alumnus, Douglas H.
Thomas Jr., of the Baltimore firm,
Parker, Thomas and Rice. It is the embodiment of Hopkins' extension into the
fields of the Humanities and Social
Sciences.
The importance of Gilman does not
lie solely in its heritage. It is
Homewood's largest classroom and office facility. In addition, its size and
central location on campus have made
Gilman attractive for other services to
the community.
Furthermore, Gilman is. a beautiful
example of collegiate Georgian revival
style architecture. Preserving this example has become the concern of the Commission on Historic and Architectural
Preservation (CHAP). In City Council
Ordinance 1764, CHAP recommends
that Gilman be designated a historic
landmark.

The administration is resisting the
designation— and with good reason.
The ordinance, if passed, would require
that any proposed changes in Gilman's
exterior would have to obtain CHAP's
approval in addition to the existing requirements from city agencies.
Gilman's historical and emotional
role at Hopkins is sufficient to insure
that it will be well taken care of in the
future. The university does not have the
flexibility of space, however, not to
make the most of every building.
The services in the basement of
Gilman would be well incorporated into a student union, one much more comprehensive than Levering Hall is today.
Although such a student union is only
a hope for the not-too-distant future, the
freeing-up of that basement space
should be well used. Gilman's designation as a historic landmark would undoubtedly slow down, and might well
interfere with its effective use, while
protecting a landmark the university is
already very sensitive to protect.

Score fest continues
by Laura Perlinn
The women's varsity field
hockey team continued their winning ways this past week beating
Dickinson 3-1 on Saturday and
crushing Division I UMBC 6-0
on Tuesday. The only down note
was a 2-0 loss to Gettysburg on
the previous Thursday. The 2-1
record for the week brings the
Lady Jays' totals to four wins and
only one loss, their best start in
recent years.
According to coach Sally Beth
Anderson, senior Heather Klink
was one of the key players in the
UMBC trouncing. "Just like Patti
Ordonez sparked the team on
Saturday against Dickinson,
Heather was the 'spark-of-theday' today against UMBC."
In the Dickinson contest, JHU
jumped ahead 2-0 in the first half,
a lead that turned out to be insurmountable. Klink opened the
scoring four minutes into the
game by shooting in a deflection
off a Dickinson defender. Ordonez tallied Hopkins' second
goal, and after Dickinson scored
their only point, April Savoye
tapped in a pass from Klink to ice
the victory late in the first half.
A solid defensive effort shut out
Dickinson in the second half.
In the scoring fest against
UMBC, Savoye deflected in a

Klink free hit for the first goal
Kacie White scored the second
goal on a penalty corner on a pass
from Jackie Fatula.
Savoye scored her second, and
Hopkins' third, of the game on
another penalty corner. Fatula
then scored just nine seconds later
after chasing the ball down field
and flicking in the goalie's rebound. Thirty-four seconds into
the second half, Rowena Tena
pushed in Julie Siegrist's shot-ongoal to raise the score to 5-0.
Fatula then flicked in the last goal
after a scramble in front of the
cage.
Goalie Jen O'Hara earned her
first shut-out of the year, due to
a great performance from O'Hara
and the defense. "Freshman
Meredith Blitz has been very consistant at left halfback. She played
a great game and has been very
dependable," Anderson stated.
Anderson was pleased to have
such a big win over a Division I
school, but she also noted that the
most important games are coming up, when the team faces
MAC division rivals Franklin &
Marshall at Homewood on
Thursday, September 24 and
Juniata away on Saturday. With
these wins, Hopkins would be in
running away with the MAC
Southeast Division Title.
